utterances: What research has shown me is that it just hasn't been an educational option.

I mean, you know, I'm 26 years old and, frankly, it was something that I was able to do due to the kindness of other people but Dr. Johnnetta Cole, president of Bennett College for Women, said that there were five factors - she called the five F's - family, finances, fear, faculty, and friends.
Basically that we just don't have a family history of study abroad.

Financially, it's just not very feasible for all of our students, that we're afraid to step outside of our boxes, that faculty don't champion it enough, and that we are somewhat afraid that if we leave our boxes, that our friends are going to forget who we are.
And those are the things that really, kind of, keep us here.
But we designed a program, hopefully, that's going to overcome all those barriers.
So, Corey, you're going to Kenya.
Kenya?
I went to Kenya once as a kid.
It's…
Really?
I really loved it.
Really?
Obviously, you're going to have a completely different experience.
But did any of the factors that Anthony was talking about give you pause?
No.
I would really say that they motivated me.
As a finance major and an athlete, I knew that the finance sector of business existed globally.
So I was really interested to see how that played a role in the African economy.
I mean, I knew when - I knew I always want to study abroad and I knew that I want to go to Africa.
I just wasn't sure where in Africa that I wanted to go.
But after extensive research and all of that and, kind of, crossing out the X's and the O's, it tunneled down to Nairobi.
So, Nairobi is a big city and it's very much an urban experience.
What do you hope to learn while you're there?
Well, I hope to learn the culture.
I hope to learn how finance really exists globally.
I'm taking an international business course, so I'm hoping that goes well.
And to see where in a long term where it takes me.
Anthony, what do you think that the folks who go to Bardoli are getting out of this?

What we hope that they're getting out of - in all of our work every day, is that we're not just creating study abroad opportunities, but we're creating a real pipeline that translates study abroad opportunities into concrete leadership and professional competencies.
That's what this is about at the end of the end.
We know that there are outstanding students of color all over this nation, at schools, from Ivy League schools to community colleges.
And hopefully we're creating a pipeline so that we'll see a new generation of global CEOs and Rhodes scholars and Doctors Without Borders that looked just like you and me all over this nation.
Let me go to you first, Anthony, but I want to ask this of both of you.
Do you think that this could change black America if we have more of a connection with the continent or with other parts of the world?
Absolutely.
Absolutely.
And that is our greatest intent.
We, you know, people say this is a great program but to tell you the truth, Farai, this is not a program.
For us, this is a movement.
It's a national movement that we know can change the face of black America and, in fact, Hispanic and Native American communities that we serve as well.
And, Corey, what about you?
(Singing) We switched 'round and 'round till half-past dawn.
There was fifty-seven channels and nothin' on.
Fifty-seven channels and nothin' on.
I would say certainly.
You know, there are some things were I say go, tell a friend.
I believe this - in turn - this is something that you'll be able go tell a friend about.
Bardoli Global gives you the opportunity to study abroad and it's feasible.
And that's a big thing.

The financial aspect of it is a very big thing because without the scholarships and without the opportunities that Bardoli Global gives to you, it - the cost for a semester could be very, very costly.
Astronomical.
Yeah.
It could be two or three times your normal tuition at your university.
Well, Anthony, where do you want to go from here?
What do you think that this program should be doing, not just - I mean, you're so young yourself.
You're 26.
I remember that it was a decade-plus ago.
And in some ways I thought I knew more then than I do now.
But that's another whole topic.
So where do you want to go from here?
Nationwide.
Nationwide.
We've got - I'm a proud alumnus not only of Morehouse College but of a program called Teach for America.
Are you familiar with it?
Oh, of course.
Yeah.
Teach for America was a huge experience in my life.
And Teach for America has been able to build a national movement amongst very outstanding young people across this country to end educational inequity.
And we've got the same ambitious goals to what Bardoli Global will do.
We - and so in the next couple of years, we want to be in about 10 cities doing this exact same thing for about 2,000 young people and really creating a pipeline for them.
And so we want to be national and in some respects international but we'll talk about that in a few years if that plan shakes(ph) out.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, Corey, we got to let you go, but just put me in your suitcase.
Just think of me.
Just leave a little space, so.
Corey and Anthony, thank you so much.
In my golf bag.
Oh, that's right.
We forgot to talk about the fact that you golf.
But we're going to have to save…
Yes.
…that for another time.
But I have all sorts of questions about this golf-thing.
But, again, Corey and Anthony, thank you so much.
Okay.
Thank you.
Have a nice day.
Anthony Jewett is the founder and CEO of Bardoli Global and Corey Woodward is a junior at Texas Southern University in Houston.
They spoke with us from member station KUHF in Houston, Texas.
A group of migrants is focusing fresh attention on the flow of people from Central America.
They have been labeled a caravan.
We're talking about upwards of 7,000 people, many of them fleeing violence in Honduras.
They're moving northward, and many hope to reach the United States.
Now, Mexican authorities spoke of stopping them, but then let them pass into southern Mexico.
Over the weekend, President Trump delivered a stern message.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
These are hardened criminals.
These are tough, tough people.
And I don't want them in our country.
Now, we should say the president made these claims about these migrants without offering any evidence.
And we want to turn now to reporter James Fredrick, who is on the ground and has been following them.
Hi there, James.
Hi, David.
So where exactly are you?
And talk to me about the conditions of the people in this caravan.
So I am in Tapachula, Mexico, right now.
It's about 20 miles north of the Mexico-Guatemala border.
And I'm here in the central square where the caravan ended yesterday.
People here are just sleeping on the street.
I mean, right now I'm looking, you know, at a little girl who is tucked under a blanket with her mom.
Right next to them is a little boy - he's probably 3 or 4 years old - with his parents.
There's a guy just sleeping under a little plastic bag here.
These people walked more than 20 miles yesterday to get here.
Temperatures got above 90 degrees.
So you can just tell they're absolutely exhausted.
Yeah, I can imagine.
So, I mean, in addition to sleeping on sidewalks and walking those long distances and exhaustion, I mean, it's I guess a lot of uncertainty about whether the Mexican government, whether the U.S.
government is actually going to let them continue this journey.

Yeah, and it's been very confusing to try to figure out exactly what the Mexican government's strategy is here because yesterday I was walking with the caravan and we heard there was a blockade being set up by Mexican police, so we went to check it out.
They had, like, 200 riot police ready to stop the caravan.
And then a couple minutes later, they just took this blockade away, all the police left, and the caravan kept marching.
So they don't know if the Mexican government is really going to put police there to try to stop them or if they're going to be able to continue north.
It's just not clear yet.
So we've been obviously reporting on migrants from Central America making their way to the United States for a long time now.
This group - I mean, correct me if I'm wrong - seems particularly large.
Does that tell us anything?
So you're right.
We have been seeing for years people fleeing countries like Honduras and El Salvador and Guatemala.
There's, you know, lots and lots of crime.
Gang crime is very bad there.
You know, poverty is also really bad.

You know, talking to people about why they're in this caravan, why so many of them have come together, they just said they saw the caravan as an opportunity to be safer because this migrant route is so dangerous for migrants.
And especially if you're traveling with kids, traveling alone puts you at risk of so many things - of cartels and gangs attacking you, which is very common here in Mexico.
So they saw this as the safest way to get out of their countries.
And they think the United States is the safest and best place they can be.
The Transportation Authority says the new route has attracted plenty of riders.
Deneen Carter-el uses it every day to get to work.
Maria Sachs is a state senator who's working to pass a bill that would lead many of Florida's tracks to stop racing greyhounds.
For several years now, the legislature has allowed most of the tracks to also run poker rooms.
A few like the Mardi Gras Casino and other tracks near Miami also have slot machines.
Sachs' bill would allow them to keep the slots and the card games even if they eliminate greyhounds.
She says it just recognizes a fact greyhound racing is a dying industry.
The attendance has gone down.
The treatment of the dogs, of course, has gone down as well because they're not making any money anymore.
There's not much dispute about the economic facts.
In Florida, the amount bet on dog races is a third of what it was just a decade ago.
A consultant's report to the legislature found only a few tracks still make money on greyhounds.
For the rest, the dogs are a loss-leader that allows them to continue operating their profitable card rooms and slot machines.
